description: From Middle English infaunt, borrowed from Latin īnfantem, accusative masculine singular of īnfāns, nominal use of the adjective meaning 'not able to speak', from īn- (“not”) + fāns, present participle of for (“to speak”). The verb is from Anglo-Norman enfanter, from the same Latin source. Doublet of infante.

entries.meaning: A very young human being, from conception to somewhere between six months and two years of age after birth, needing almost constant care and attention.

examples: Thomas Humphrey Doleman died the 30th of August 1712, an infant, intestate and without issue; Lewis the next nephew died the 17th of April 1716, an infant about sixteen years old, having left his mother Mary Webb, ...

verbs.description: infant (third-person singular simple present infants, present participle infanting, simple past and past participle infanted)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To bear or bring forth (a child); to produce, in general.
